<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/13/nba-investigates-spencer-dinwiddies-attempt-tokenize-contract-blockchain?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Is Spencer Dinwiddie Actually Satoshi Nakamoto? An Investigation.
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="An illustration of Spencer Dinwiddie playing basketball with a bitcoin ball" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTc4OTU1MTUyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Brooklyn Nets point guard Spencer Dinwiddie launched his token-based investment vehicle, and every kid who once dreamed of being an NBA GM said, "actually...I'll pass."   </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">It's that complicated. </strong>Last September, Dinwiddie <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/shlomosprung/2019/10/17/spencer-dinwiddie-discusses-digital-tokenization-plan-happening-against-the-nbas-wishes/#757e18376dc0?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">revealed a plan</a> to create a blockchain-based investment platform called DREAM Fan Shares. The goal was to sell 90 "SD8" tokens <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2019/09/16/nba-2020-olympics-get-emerging-tech-treatment?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">backed by his contract</a> (a three-year, $34 million deal), allowing Dinwiddie to collect $13.5 million upfront.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Think of the tokens as a three-year "Spencer Dinwiddie bond" that will pay out a 4.95% base interest each month.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Only accredited investors can get involved; the minimum payment is $150,000. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why invest? </strong>Warren Buffett couldn't find a better value stock than Dinwiddie. He's one of the most improved players in the NBA, and his contract is "regarded in league circles as a bargain given his production," <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/27/sports/basketball/spencer-dinwiddie-nets-invest.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the NYT writes</a>. He's currently <a href="https://www.sbnation.com/nba/2019/12/9/21002329/spencer-dinwiddies-brooklyn-nets-stats-highlights-clutch-kyrie-irving-all-star?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">in the running</a> for the All-Star Game.  </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The NBA fought back</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After reading a few Reddit threads on blockchain, the NBA decided portions of Dinwiddie's plan <a href="https://www.si.com/nba/nets/news/spencer-dinwiddie-is-defiant-while-his-nba-contract-escalates-a-feud?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">violated</a> its collective bargaining agreement, which states that "no player shall assign or otherwise transfer to any third party his right to receive compensation from the team under his uniform player contract."</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The league threatened to ban Dinwiddie for what he </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/SDinwiddie_25/status/1215640393204871168?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">called</a></span><span> "some fun stuff with his contract." </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When Dinwiddie made his contract less fun, the two sides reached some level of understanding. But the NBA released a <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-13/nba-reviews-nets-player-s-plan-to-sell-bond-tied-to-earnings?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">statement</a> yesterday saying it still needed to "determine whether the updated idea is permissible under league rules." </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>What Dinwiddie is doing isn't totally new—after all, David Bowie issued "<a href="https://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/bowie-bond.asp?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Bowie bonds</a>" in 1997 using the singer's current and future revenue as collateral. But the move does show how today's NBA players are pushing the league's boundaries. And if successful, <a href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/shlomosprung/2019/10/17/spencer-dinwiddie-discusses-digital-tokenization-plan-happening-against-the-nbas-wishes/#757e18376dc0?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Forbes writes</a>, the Spencer Dinwiddie bond would "revolutionize the way professional athletes own their own brands and intellectual property." </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/13/steph-korey-return-luggage-company-away-coceo?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Live Look at Steph Korey
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="A gif of the Arrested Development "I've made a huge mistake" meme " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=373 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/11BAxHG7paxJcI/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="A gif of the Arrested Development " I've made a huge mistake" meme " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/11BAxHG7paxJcI/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Steph Korey slept on it, and she changed her mind: She's <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/13/business/steph-korey-away.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">coming back</a> to Away, the direct-to-consumer luggage startup, as co-CEO.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What "it" is: </strong>In December, an <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2019/12/5/20995453/away-luggage-ceo-steph-korey-toxic-work-environment-travel-inclusion?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">article in The Verge</a> quoted former employees who described a "toxic work environment" enabled, and often perpetrated, by the CEO Korey. Following a social media firestorm, Korey apologized and said she would step aside as chief executive but remain on the board.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Monday morning, the company hit everyone with the ol' "jk." Lululemon COO Stuart Haselden, who was tapped as the new Away CEO, will now share the role with Korey. And Away is turning defense into offense: Per the NYT, it hired the same lawyer who successfully sued Rolling Stone over its retracted "A Rape on Campus" article about a UVA fraternity.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the plan is for Haselden to eventually take full operational control after a transition period. But it is unique for a brand to rebuke the social media audience that made it successful in the first place. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BANKING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/13/banks-first-quarterly-earnings-reports?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Banks Are Ready to Earn Your Attention
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Skyscrapers in Charlotte " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTc4OTU1NzQwLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We're already six pancakes deep waiting for JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, and Citigroup to report quarterly earnings this morning. They’ll tell us whether the economy will emerge from flu season unscathed. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Bad news first</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Fed dropped interest rates last year, which cut into lending profits. In response, banks are now <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/bank-stocks-had-a-bonanza-in-2019-earnings-will-be-more-blah-11578834001?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">doubling down</a> on less volatile businesses like wealth management. Trade war uncertainty also trimmed the growth of commercial and industrial loans as businesses paused new investments.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">But lower rates taketh and giveth</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Invigorated consumers borrowed heaps to spend on big-ticket items like houses and cars. That's good news for banks with big mortgage arms (Wells Fargo, JPMorgan). </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">More good vibes: </strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The KBW Bank Index </span><span><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/12/investing/stocks-week-ahead/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rose</a></span><span> about 13% in Q4. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Fed is expected to hold rates steady this year. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The booming stock market kept trading revenues up. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Big banks earned more than $120 billion in combined profit in 2018, a record. Let's see if they can top it in 2019. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we're here: </strong>Today is also Charles Scharf's first earnings report as Wells Fargo's new CEO. Reuters <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-wells-fargo-scharf/new-wells-fargo-ceo-brings-wall-street-swagger-to-storied-bank-idUSKBN1ZC21O?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">says</a> he's not the bedtime-story type.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENTERTAINMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/13/oscar-announcement-netflix-gets-cold-shoulder-theater-chains?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Netflix Gets Nod in Drama Category
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Marraige Story meme " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC83MTEzL21hcnJhaWdlX3N0b3J5X21lbWUucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Marriage Story / Netflix</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We're not talking about the 16 combined Oscar nods for <em>The Irishman </em>and <em>Marriage Story</em>. After Netflix secured more <a href="https://oscar.go.com/news/nominations/oscar-nominations-2020-list-nominees-by-category?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nominations</a> than any other studio yesterday, two leading theater chains reminded us they're in an all-out war with the streaming company.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">AMC Theatres and Regal Cinemas, which traditionally show films nominated for best picture leading up to the Academy Awards, <a href="https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/business/story/2020-01-13/oscar-nominations-2020-amc-regal-theaters-boycott-netflix?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">will not</a> give Netflix any screen space after it sidestepped traditional theatrical releases for those films. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>To meet the Academy's release requirement for best picture consideration, Netflix relied on a network of independent theaters.</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Other notes </h2>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><em>Joker</em></span><span> led with 11 nominations.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Some critics </span><span><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/arts-entertainment/2020/01/13/this-years-biggest-oscar-snubs-adam-sandler-jennifer-lopez-women-directing-movies/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">panned</a></span><span> the Academy for failing to nominate a single female director and for not handing more nominations to films like </span><span><em>Little Women</em></span><span>, </span><span><em>Hustlers</em></span><span>,</span><span><em> Us,</em></span><span> and </span><span><em>The Farewell</em></span><span>, which featured strong female leads.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Disney's </span><span><em>Frozen II</em></span><span><span>, the highest-grossing animated movie ever, was expected to contend for best animated feature...but </span></span><span><a href="https://www.polygon.com/2020/1/13/21063498/oscars-2020-frozen-2-snub-disney-netflix-animation?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">didn't</a></span><span><span> get the nomination. Netflix's Christmas flick </span></span><span><em>Klaus</em></span><span><span> did—which could be a sign its independent animation studio is gaining steam.</span></span><span>
</span>
</li>
</ul>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPONSORED BY THE MOTLEY FOOL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
549% Is a Lot of Percents
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.fool.com/mms/mark/sa-earlybird?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=earlybird&aid=8969&paid=8969&waid=8969&source=esamnbwdg0210031&psource=esamnbwdg0210031&wsource=esamnbwdg0210031" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="The Motley Fool " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTc4OTM2NDUwLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We aren’t math majors, but we know a big number when we see one. And that one up there might seem like the odds I’ll eat pizza alone tonight, but actually it signifies David Gardner’s average stock pick returns over the last few <em>decades</em>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Don’t know David Gardner? He’s a stock-picking legend. So when he says, “Buy,” we say, “Mom and dad can we get an advance on our birthday money?”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You saw this coming, but <a href="https://www.fool.com/mms/mark/sa-earlybird?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=earlybird&aid=8969&paid=8969&waid=8969&source=esamnbwdg0210031&psource=esamnbwdg0210031&wsource=esamnbwdg0210031" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">David’s got a tech stock he can’t stop recommending</a>. In fact, he issued a “Buy” alert on this stock mere months after the company IPO’d—then recommended the same stock again a few months later.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://www.fool.com/mms/mark/sa-earlybird?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=contentmarketing&utm_campaign=earlybird&aid=8969&paid=8969&waid=8969&source=esamnbwdg0210031&psource=esamnbwdg0210031&wsource=esamnbwdg0210031" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Take David’s advice and buy</a>.</p>
</td>
</tr>

</th>
</tr>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WELLBEING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/13/study-pinpoints-age-472-peak-misery?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
I'm Not Mad, I'm Just 47.2
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Maybe Peter Pan had it right all along. New research shows that <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-13/middle-age-misery-peaks-at-age-of-47-2-economist-says?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">peak misery</a> in developed countries happens at 47.2 years old.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a <a href="https://www.nber.org/papers/w26641?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">working paper</a> for the National Bureau of Economic Research, Dartmouth College Professor David Blanchflower found that in 132 countries studied there is a U-shaped "happiness curve." In advanced countries, that curve hits its minimum at 47.2; in developing countries, 48.2. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>He found the U-shaped curve was present after controlling for education, marital, and employment status and often after not controlling for those variables at all. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>In a <a href="https://www.nber.org/papers/w26642?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">separate paper</a> called "Unhappiness and age," Blanchflower links reduced middle-age wellbeing to the financial crisis and trade. "The resiliency of communities left behind by globalization was diminished by the Great Recession which made it especially hard for the vulnerable undergoing a midlife crisis with few resources, to withstand the shock."</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PODCAST
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
What Happens When the VC Music Stops?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Business Casual logo " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTc0MzcwMDU5LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You know what happens when you assume: You make a terrible investment mistake. So why are so many startup founders and everyday investors assuming today’s endless well of venture capital is...actually endless?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This week on Morning Brew’s weekly podcast, </strong><strong style="color:#000"><em>Business Casual</em></strong><strong style="color:#000">,</strong> Union Square Ventures Managing Partner Rebecca Kaden explains that, even though venture as a whole is armed with more capital than ever before, “nerves are spiking and we know change is coming.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But what does that change look like? And when the change comes, where can you find opportunity in a venture-funded world packed with potential WeWorks (no offense)?  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Kaden dives into all that, plus...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Why the inherent risk of venture capital is misconceived by the market</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Why recessions are good for venture capitalists but bad for you</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>How her economic predictions compare with those of Juicy J</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Listen here:</strong> <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/Kaden_Apple?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Apple</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/Kaden_Spotify?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Spotify</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/Kaden_All?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">everywhere else</a></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BREW'S BETS
</h3>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Written by
<a href="https://twitter.com/Neal_Freyman" class="link" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Neal Freyman</a>, <a href="https://twitter.com/its_ahickey" class="link" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Alex Hickey</a>, and <a href="https://twitter.com/KinseyGrant" class="link" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Kinsey Grant</a>

An Investigation.\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"An illustration of Spencer Dinwiddie playing basketball with a bitcoin ball\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiIxNTc4OTU1MTUyLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im1vcm5pbmdicmV3LW9zbG8iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Brooklyn Nets point guard Spencer Dinwiddie launched his token-based investment vehicle, and every kid who once dreamed of being an NBA GM said, \"actually...I'll pass.\"   \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIt's that complicated. \u003c/strong\u003eLast September, Dinwiddie \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/shlomosprung/2019/10/17/spencer-dinwiddie-discusses-digital-tokenization-plan-happening-against-the-nbas-wishes/#757e18376dc0?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erevealed a plan\u003c/a\u003e to create a blockchain-based investment platform called DREAM Fan Shares. The goal was to sell 90 \"SD8\" tokens \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/emerging-tech/stories/2019/09/16/nba-2020-olympics-get-emerging-tech-treatment?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebacked by his contract\u003c/a\u003e (a three-year, $34 million deal), allowing Dinwiddie to collect $13.5 million upfront.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThink of the tokens as a three-year \"Spencer Dinwiddie bond\" that will pay out a 4.95% base interest each month.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOnly accredited investors can get involved; the minimum payment is $150,000. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy invest? \u003c/strong\u003eWarren Buffett couldn't find a better value stock than Dinwiddie. He's one of the most improved players in the NBA, and his contract is \"regarded in league circles as a bargain given his production,\" \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/27/sports/basketball/spencer-dinwiddie-nets-invest.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethe NYT writes\u003c/a\u003e. He's currently \u003ca href=\"https://www.sbnation.com/nba/2019/12/9/21002329/spencer-dinwiddies-brooklyn-nets-stats-highlights-clutch-kyrie-irving-all-star?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ein the running\u003c/a\u003e for the All-Star Game.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe NBA fought back\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAfter reading a few Reddit threads on blockchain, the NBA decided portions of Dinwiddie's plan \u003ca href=\"https://www.si.com/nba/nets/news/spencer-dinwiddie-is-defiant-while-his-nba-contract-escalates-a-feud?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eviolated\u003c/a\u003e its collective bargaining agreement, which states that \"no player shall assign or otherwise transfer to any third party his right to receive compensation from the team under his uniform player contract.\"\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe league threatened to ban Dinwiddie for what he \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/SDinwiddie_25/status/1215640393204871168?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecalled\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e \"some fun stuff with his contract.\" \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen Dinwiddie made his contract less fun, the two sides reached some level of understanding. But the NBA released a \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-13/nba-reviews-nets-player-s-plan-to-sell-bond-tied-to-earnings?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estatement\u003c/a\u003e yesterday saying it still needed to \"determine whether the updated idea is permissible under league rules.\" \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eWhat Dinwiddie is doing isn't totally new—after all, David Bowie issued \"\u003ca href=\"https://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/bowie-bond.asp?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBowie bonds\u003c/a\u003e\" in 1997 using the singer's current and future revenue as collateral. But the move does show how today's NBA players are pushing the league's boundaries. And if successful, \u003ca href=\"https://www.forbes.com/sites/shlomosprung/2019/10/17/spencer-dinwiddie-discusses-digital-tokenization-plan-happening-against-the-nbas-wishes/#757e18376dc0?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eForbes writes\u003c/a\u003e, the Spencer Dinwiddie bond would \"revolutionize the way professional athletes own their own brands and intellectual property.\" \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/13/business/steph-korey-away.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecoming back\u003c/a\u003e to Away, the direct-to-consumer luggage startup, as co-CEO.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat \"it\" is: \u003c/strong\u003eIn December, an \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2019/12/5/20995453/away-luggage-ceo-steph-korey-toxic-work-environment-travel-inclusion?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003earticle in The Verge\u003c/a\u003e quoted former employees who described a \"toxic work environment\" enabled, and often perpetrated, by the CEO Korey. Following a social media firestorm, Korey apologized and said she would step aside as chief executive but remain on the board.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMonday morning, the company hit everyone with the ol' \"jk.\" Lululemon COO Stuart Haselden, who was tapped as the new Away CEO, will now share the role with Korey. And Away is turning defense into offense: Per the NYT, it hired the same lawyer who successfully sued Rolling Stone over its retracted \"A Rape on Campus\" article about a UVA fraternity.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe plan is for Haselden to eventually take full operational control after a transition period. But it is unique for a brand to rebuke the social media audience that made it successful in the first place. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe're already six pancakes deep waiting for JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, and Citigroup to report quarterly earnings this morning. They’ll tell us whether the economy will emerge from flu season unscathed. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBad news first\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Fed dropped interest rates last year, which cut into lending profits. In response, banks are now \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/bank-stocks-had-a-bonanza-in-2019-earnings-will-be-more-blah-11578834001?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edoubling down\u003c/a\u003e on less volatile businesses like wealth management. Trade war uncertainty also trimmed the growth of commercial and industrial loans as businesses paused new investments.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBut lower rates taketh and giveth\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eInvigorated consumers borrowed heaps to spend on big-ticket items like houses and cars. That's good news for banks with big mortgage arms (Wells Fargo, JPMorgan). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMore good vibes: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe KBW Bank Index \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/01/12/investing/stocks-week-ahead/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erose\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e about 13% in Q4. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Fed is expected to hold rates steady this year. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe booming stock market kept trading revenues up. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBig banks earned more than $120 billion in combined profit in 2018, a record. Let's see if they can top it in 2019. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ While we're here: \u003c/strong\u003eToday is also Charles Scharf's first earnings report as Wells Fargo's new CEO. New research shows that \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-13/middle-age-misery-peaks-at-age-of-47-2-economist-says?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epeak misery\u003c/a\u003e in developed countries happens at 47.2 years old.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn a \u003ca href=\"https://www.nber.org/papers/w26641?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eworking paper\u003c/a\u003e for the National Bureau of Economic Research, Dartmouth College Professor David Blanchflower found that in 132 countries studied there is a U-shaped \"happiness curve.\" In advanced countries, that curve hits its minimum at 47.2; in developing countries, 48.2. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHe found the U-shaped curve was present after controlling for education, marital, and employment status and often after not controlling for those variables at all. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eIn a \u003ca href=\"https://www.nber.org/papers/w26642?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eseparate paper\u003c/a\u003e called \"Unhappiness and age,\" Blanchflower links reduced middle-age wellbeing to the financial crisis and trade. \"The resiliency of communities left behind by globalization was diminished by the Great Recession which made it especially hard for the vulnerable undergoing a midlife crisis with few resources, to withstand the shock.\"\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F01%2F13%2Fstudy-pinpoints-age-472-peak-misery\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block;
